comment_text.dn29:1.2: The Vedhaññās are not mentioned elsewhere; their name means “Marksmen”.
comment_text.dn29:1.3: When this event is mentioned at MN 104:2.1, the Buddha is also in the Sakyan lands, but near the village of Sāma. Both texts tell the story of Cunda conveying the news via Ānanda at Sāma, which was presumably near the Vedhaññā’s mango grove. It does seem strange that two distinct discourses are recorded from the same prompt, but then, why shouldn’t the Buddha give more than one teaching on such an important topic? At DN 33:1.6.1 the Buddha is at Pāvā in the Mallian lands, and the discourse is spoken by Sāriputta there. Given the evident lateness of DN 33, this is a less convincing framework. A parallel to MN 104 (MA 196 at T i 752c12) says he was in the Vajjian lands at the time; both Sakya and Vajji border on Mallā. Jain tradition holds Mahāvīra died after the Buddha, and it was at a different Pāvā in Magadha near Nāḷandā, perhaps the place known in Pali as Pāvārika’s mango grove (DN 11:1.2). The earliest Jain source for Mahāvīra’s death, the Kalpasutra, is, however, much later than the Buddhist sources, and does not say where Pāvā is. But it does say the events were commemorated by the rulers of Kāsī and Kosala, and the Mallians and the Licchavīs. The absence of Magadha and the presence of Malla sit better with the location of Pāvā in Malla rather than Magadha.
comment_text.dn29:1.4: While this description of the Jains might seem like sheer sectarian calumny, it is a fact that the Jain tradition is split into two sects, the “sky-clad” Digambara, whose male ascetics went naked, and the “white-clad” Śvetāmbara who wear an unstitched cloth. Jain tradition holds that the split occurred about a century later, in the reign of Candragupta Maurya.
comment_text.dn29:1.6: A slight on the movement whose signature virtue was non-violence.
comment_text.dn29:1.7: “With broken monument” (bhinnathupe) is used only in this context. When a great teacher or leader died, a “monument” was built to keep their memory alive. The breaking of a monument—whether physical or symbolic—was, in a way, truly killing them.
comment_text.dn29:2.1: Cunda took the time to complete his rains residence before conveying the news, reminding us of the speed with which news traveled in those days—slowly. | Apart from the events described here, we hear of Sāma only once (AN 6.21). The topic there is the decline of the Saṅgha, hinting at a connection with these events.
comment_text.dn29:4.1: This harsh critique is repeated at DN 33:1.7.4, but not at MN 104:5.1, where the Buddha’s response focuses on his own community.
comment_text.dn29:4.3: Normally we find vokkamma (“having turned away”) in the sense of straying from the Dhamma. But this passage shows the phrase is, in itself, neutral, as it is good to turn from a bad teaching.
comment_text.dn29:4.8: The Dhamma is primary, not the teacher. This is applied to Buddhism as well; for example, a student is expected to help a mentor who is falling away from Dhamma (Kd 1:25.20.1).
comment_text.dn29:8.2: “Collected sayings” is saṅgāhapada. This is a unique term, but the sense seems to be that the process of gathering and organizing teachings is incomplete. I take the negative na to be distributed separately among the clauses.
comment_text.dn29:16.8: One of the Brahmanical sages under whom the Bodhisatta practiced before awakening (MN 26:16.1). Another of his enigmatic sayings is found at SN 35.103:1.2. When the Bodhisatta began his study, he first learned to recite the scriptures, and in these two passages we find examples of what those scriptures were.
comment_text.dn29:16.11: Sharp razors were known even in Vedic times (Rig Veda 8.4.16).
comment_text.dn29:16.13: This is a distorted reference to Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.7. There, the Self is said to be hidden in a body like a razor in its case. People do not see it (taṁ na paśyanti), for they only see the partial and incomplete functions of the Self, such as breathing, speaking, and so on. Seeing only the aspects, they do not see that each aspect is an expression of the one whole. This confirms that Uddaka was a Brahmanical teacher who was familiar with this passage. Similar phrases, but without the razor simile, are found at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.23 and Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.12.1.
comment_text.dn29:17.1: “Recite in concert” is saṅgīti. Reciting together affirms the mutual teaching and ensures the correctness of the text. The implication is that the entire Buddhist community participates, but in the saṅgīti after the Buddha’s death there were only monks.
comment_text.dn29:17.3: Here the Buddha outlines the topics to be recited, which are the main chapters of the Saṁyutta Nikāya.
comment_text.dn29:18.4: The “meaning” is the attha. Here we see the source of the atthakathā, which we translate as “commentaries”, but which are literally “discussions on the meaning”. Such discussions are undertaken through a civil and polite inquiry.
comment_text.dn29:18.5: Meaning and phrasing are interdependent, so care must be taken with both. Often it happens that when the phrasing slips, a new and unwarranted meaning is imputed.
comment_text.dn29:22.5: These are the four basic requisites for monastics, said to overcome defilements by usage (AN 6.58:4.1, MN 2:13.1).
comment_text.dn29:23.2: This repurposes the phrase used right at the beginning of the Buddha’s first teaching, the Dhammacakkappavattasutta (SN 56.11:2.3). There he was persuading hard-bitten ascetics that he did not indulge in sensual pleasures. While the affiliation of those five ascetics is not stated explicitly, clearly their practices were similar to the Jains. And given the context, no doubt the Buddha has the Jains in mind here.
comment_text.dn29:24.5: Again echoing the first sermon (SN 56.11:3.1), here the Buddha places the jhānas where, in the Dhammacakkappavattasutta, he put the middle way. He uses a similar strategy at DN 28:19.2.
comment_text.dn29:25.14: Some meditation teachers warn of the supposed dangers of becoming attached to the pleasure of meditation. The Buddha’s view was that the pleasure of meditation arises from letting go and leads to Nibbana.
comment_text.dn29:26.2: At AN 8.19:3.1 the ocean is said to be ṭhitadhammo, “naturally stable”. Both places are glossed as ṭhitasabhāvā. It seems this is in reference to the fact that the Buddhist Vinaya is gentle and flexible. The Buddha was ready to alter and adjust details when circumstances required, yet the fundamental principles hold firm.
comment_text.dn29:27.3: It is possible to remember the past, but knowledge of the future is restricted to inferences in specific contexts and cannot be predicted in general.
comment_text.dn29:27.6: The Buddha claims no gift of prophecy, unlike some other sages, but he knows that which matters.
comment_text.dn29:30.2: Here these questions follow on from the Buddha’s acknowledgment of epistemological limitations. Not everything can be known, and if it is, it is not always useful to speak of it.
comment_text.dn29:34.13: The idea “made by oneself” (sayaṅkata) assumes a metaphysical “self” which creates “the self and the cosmos”. This implies the Vedic creation doctrine, whereby Prajāpati created the cosmos and all things in it from himself by an act of self-sacrifice. Thus the sacrificer offers to Prajāpati as the sun with the words, “You are self-made” (svāṁkṛta, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 4.1.1.22, 4.1.2.21). For more details on this teaching, see SN 12.17 and notes there.
comment_text.dn29:40.1: The Brahmajālasutta describes the path to the end of these views in terms of understanding dependent origination through contemplation of contact in the six senses (DN 1:3.71.12). The Buddhist path is integrated, so one part always implies the whole.

root_text.dn29:14.1: Ahaṁ kho pana, cunda, etarahi satthā loke uppanno arahaṁ sammāsambuddho.
root_text.dn29:14.2: Dhammo ca svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṁvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito.
root_text.dn29:14.3: Viññāpitatthā ca me sāvakā saddhamme, kevalañca tesaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ āvikataṁ uttānīkataṁ sabbasaṅgāhapadakataṁ sappāṭihīrakataṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ.
root_text.dn29:14.4: Ahaṁ kho pana, cunda, etarahi satthā thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.

root_text.dn29:16.1: Yāvatā kho, cunda, etarahi satthāro loke uppannā, nāhaṁ, cunda, aññaṁ ekasatthārampi samanupassāmi evaṁlābhaggayasaggappattaṁ yatharivāhaṁ.
root_text.dn29:16.2: Yāvatā kho pana, cunda, etarahi saṅgho vā gaṇo vā loke uppanno;
root_text.dn29:16.3: nāhaṁ, cunda, aññaṁ ekasaṅghampi samanupassāmi evaṁlābhaggayasaggappattaṁ yatharivāyaṁ, cunda, bhikkhusaṅgho.
root_text.dn29:16.4: Yaṁ kho taṁ, cunda, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
root_text.dn29:16.5: ‘sabbākārasampannaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ anūnamanadhikaṁ svākkhātaṁ kevalaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ suppakāsitan’ti.
root_text.dn29:16.8: Udako sudaṁ, cunda, rāmaputto evaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati:
root_text.dn29:16.11: Khurassa sādhunisitassa talamassa passati, dhārañca khvassa na passati.
root_text.dn29:16.14: Yaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, udakena rāmaputtena bhāsitaṁ hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ khurameva sandhāya.
root_text.dn29:16.15: Yañca taṁ, cunda, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
root_text.dn29:16.16: ‘passaṁ na passatī’ti, idameva taṁ sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
root_text.dn29:16.19: Evaṁ sabbākārasampannaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ anūnamanadhikaṁ svākkhātaṁ kevalaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ suppakāsitanti, iti hetaṁ passati.
root_text.dn29:16.20: Idamettha apakaḍḍheyya, evaṁ taṁ parisuddhataraṁ assāti, iti hetaṁ na passati.
root_text.dn29:16.21: Idamettha upakaḍḍheyya, evaṁ taṁ paripūraṁ assāti, iti hetaṁ na passati.
root_text.dn29:16.24: Yaṁ kho taṁ, cunda, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
root_text.dn29:16.28: ‘sabbākārasampannaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ anūnamanadhikaṁ svākkhātaṁ kevalaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ suppakāsitan’ti.
root_text.dn29:17.1: Tasmātiha, cunda, ye vo mayā dhammā abhiññā desitā, tattha sabbeheva saṅgamma samāgamma atthena atthaṁ byañjanena byañjanaṁ saṅgāyitabbaṁ na vivaditabbaṁ, yathayidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ addhaniyaṁ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṁ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.
root_text.dn29:17.2: Katame ca te, cunda, dhammā mayā abhiññā desitā, yattha sabbeheva saṅgamma samāgamma atthena atthaṁ byañjanena byañjanaṁ saṅgāyitabbaṁ na vivaditabbaṁ, yathayidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ addhaniyaṁ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṁ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ?
root_text.dn29:17.3: Seyyathidaṁ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, cattāro sammappadhānā, cattāro iddhipādā, pañcindriyāni, pañca balāni, satta bojjhaṅgā, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo.
root_text.dn29:17.4: Ime kho te, cunda, dhammā mayā abhiññā desitā.
root_text.dn29:17.5: Yattha sabbeheva saṅgamma samāgamma atthena atthaṁ byañjanena byañjanaṁ saṅgāyitabbaṁ na vivaditabbaṁ, yathayidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ addhaniyaṁ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṁ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.
root_text.dn29:18.1: Tesañca vo, cunda, samaggānaṁ sammodamānānaṁ avivadamānānaṁ sikkhataṁ aññataro sabrahmacārī saṅghe dhammaṁ bhāseyya.
root_text.dn29:18.3: ‘ayaṁ kho āyasmā atthañceva micchā gaṇhāti, byañjanāni ca micchā ropetī’ti.
root_text.dn29:18.4: Tassa neva abhinanditabbaṁ na paṭikkositabbaṁ, anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā so evamassa vacanīyo:
root_text.dn29:18.5: ‘imassa nu kho, āvuso, atthassa imāni vā byañjanāni etāni vā byañjanāni katamāni opāyikatarāni, imesañca byañjanānaṁ ayaṁ vā attho eso vā attho katamo opāyikataro’ti?
root_text.dn29:18.7: ‘imassa kho, āvuso, atthassa imāneva byañjanāni opāyikatarāni, yā ceva etāni; imesañca byañjanānaṁ ayameva attho opāyikataro, yā ceva eso’ti.
root_text.dn29:18.8: So neva ussādetabbo na apasādetabbo, anussādetvā anapasādetvā sveva sādhukaṁ saññāpetabbo tassa ca atthassa tesañca byañjanānaṁ nisantiyā.
root_text.dn29:19.1: Aparopi ce, cunda, sabrahmacārī saṅghe dhammaṁ bhāseyya.
root_text.dn29:19.3: ‘ayaṁ kho āyasmā atthañhi kho micchā gaṇhāti byañjanāni sammā ropetī’ti.
root_text.dn29:19.4: Tassa neva abhinanditabbaṁ na paṭikkositabbaṁ, anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā so evamassa vacanīyo:
root_text.dn29:19.5: ‘imesaṁ nu kho, āvuso, byañjanānaṁ ayaṁ vā attho eso vā attho katamo opāyikataro’ti?
root_text.dn29:19.7: ‘imesaṁ kho, āvuso, byañjanānaṁ ayameva attho opāyikataro, yā ceva eso’ti.
root_text.dn29:19.8: So neva ussādetabbo na apasādetabbo, anussādetvā anapasādetvā sveva sādhukaṁ saññāpetabbo tasseva atthassa nisantiyā.
root_text.dn29:20.1: Aparopi ce, cunda, sabrahmacārī saṅghe dhammaṁ bhāseyya.
root_text.dn29:20.3: ‘ayaṁ kho āyasmā atthañhi kho sammā gaṇhāti byañjanāni micchā ropetī’ti.
root_text.dn29:20.4: Tassa neva abhinanditabbaṁ na paṭikkositabbaṁ; anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā so evamassa vacanīyo:
root_text.dn29:20.5: ‘imassa nu kho, āvuso, atthassa imāni vā byañjanāni etāni vā byañjanāni katamāni opāyikatarānī’ti?
root_text.dn29:20.7: ‘imassa kho, āvuso, atthassa imāneva byañjanāni opayikatarāni, yā ceva etānī’ti.
root_text.dn29:20.8: So neva ussādetabbo na apasādetabbo; anussādetvā anapasādetvā sveva sādhukaṁ saññāpetabbo tesaññeva byañjanānaṁ nisantiyā.
root_text.dn29:21.1: Aparopi ce, cunda, sabrahmacārī saṅghe dhammaṁ bhāseyya.
root_text.dn29:21.3: ‘ayaṁ kho āyasmā atthañceva sammā gaṇhāti byañjanāni ca sammā ropetī’ti.
root_text.dn29:21.5: tassa ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā so evamassa vacanīyo:
root_text.dn29:21.7: ye mayaṁ āyasmantaṁ tādisaṁ sabrahmacāriṁ passāma evaṁ atthupetaṁ byañjanupetan’ti.
root_text.dn29:22.1: Na vo ahaṁ, cunda, diṭṭhadhammikānaṁyeva āsavānaṁ saṁvarāya dhammaṁ desemi.
root_text.dn29:22.2: Na panāhaṁ, cunda, samparāyikānaṁyeva āsavānaṁ paṭighātāya dhammaṁ desemi.
root_text.dn29:22.3: Diṭṭhadhammikānaṁ cevāhaṁ, cunda, āsavānaṁ saṁvarāya dhammaṁ desemi;
root_text.dn29:22.5: Tasmātiha, cunda, yaṁ vo mayā cīvaraṁ anuññātaṁ, alaṁ vo taṁ
root_text.dn29:22.6: yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya, uṇhassa paṭighātāya, ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ paṭighātāya, yāvadeva hirikopīnapaṭicchādanatthaṁ.
root_text.dn29:22.7: Yo vo mayā piṇḍapāto anuññāto, alaṁ vo so
root_text.dn29:22.8: yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā yāpanāya vihiṁsūparatiyā brahmacariyānuggahāya, iti purāṇañca vedanaṁ paṭihaṅkhāmi, navañca vedanaṁ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro ca.
root_text.dn29:22.9: Yaṁ vo mayā senāsanaṁ anuññātaṁ, alaṁ vo taṁ
root_text.dn29:22.10: yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya, uṇhassa paṭighātāya, ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ paṭighātāya, yāvadeva utuparissayavinodanapaṭisallānārāmatthaṁ.
root_text.dn29:22.11: Yo vo mayā gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāro anuññāto, alaṁ vo so
root_text.dn29:22.12: yāvadeva uppannānaṁ veyyābādhikānaṁ vedanānaṁ paṭighātāya abyāpajjaparamatāya.
root_text.dn29:23.1: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
root_text.dn29:23.3: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
root_text.dn29:23.6: Cattārome, cunda, sukhallikānuyogā hīnā gammā pothujjanikā anariyā anatthasaṁhitā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.dn29:23.8: Idha, cunda, ekacco bālo pāṇe vadhitvā vadhitvā attānaṁ sukheti pīṇeti.
root_text.dn29:23.10: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, idhekacco adinnaṁ ādiyitvā ādiyitvā attānaṁ sukheti pīṇeti.
root_text.dn29:23.12: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, idhekacco musā bhaṇitvā bhaṇitvā attānaṁ sukheti pīṇeti.
root_text.dn29:23.14: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, idhekacco pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
root_text.dn29:23.16: Ime kho, cunda, cattāro sukhallikānuyogā hīnā gammā pothujjanikā anariyā anatthasaṁhitā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.dn29:24.1: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
root_text.dn29:24.2: ‘ime cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
root_text.dn29:24.4: Na te vo sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ, abbhācikkheyyuṁ asatā abhūtena.
root_text.dn29:24.5: Cattārome, cunda, sukhallikānuyogā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.dn29:24.7: Idha, cunda, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn29:24.9: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn29:24.11: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn29:24.13: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn29:24.15: Ime kho, cunda, cattāro sukhallikānuyogā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.dn29:24.16: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
root_text.dn29:24.17: ‘ime cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
root_text.dn29:24.19: Sammā te vo vadamānā vadeyyuṁ, na te vo abbhācikkheyyuṁ asatā abhūtena.
root_text.dn29:25.1: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
root_text.dn29:25.2: ‘ime panāvuso, cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttānaṁ viharataṁ kati phalāni katānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā’ti?
root_text.dn29:25.3: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
root_text.dn29:25.4: ‘ime kho, āvuso, cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttānaṁ viharataṁ cattāri phalāni cattāro ānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
root_text.dn29:25.6: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
root_text.dn29:25.8: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karoti.
root_text.dn29:25.10: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti, tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
root_text.dn29:25.12: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn29:25.14: Ime kho, āvuso, cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttānaṁ viharataṁ imāni cattāri phalāni, cattāro ānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā’ti.
root_text.dn29:26.1: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
root_text.dn29:26.3: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
root_text.dn29:26.4: ‘atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sāvakānaṁ dhammā desitā paññattā yāvajīvaṁ anatikkamanīyā.
root_text.dn29:26.5: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, indakhīlo vā ayokhīlo vā gambhīranemo sunikhāto acalo asampavedhī;
root_text.dn29:26.6: evameva kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sāvakānaṁ dhammā desitā paññattā yāvajīvaṁ anatikkamanīyā.
root_text.dn29:26.7: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so nava ṭhānāni ajjhācarituṁ.

translation_text.dn29:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans in a stilt longhouse in a mango grove belonging to those Sakyans named Vedhaññā.
translation_text.dn29:1.3: Now at that time the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan had recently passed away at Pāvā.
translation_text.dn29:1.4: With his passing the Jain ascetics split, dividing into two factions, fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
translation_text.dn29:1.5: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
translation_text.dn29:1.6: You’d think there was nothing but slaughter going on among the Jain ascetics.
translation_text.dn29:1.7: And the Jain Ñātika’s white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics. They were equally disappointed with a teaching and training so poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha, with broken monument and without a refuge.
translation_text.dn29:2.1: And then, after completing the rainy season residence near Pāvā, the novice Cunda went to see Venerable Ānanda at Sāma village. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
translation_text.dn29:2.5: “Reverend Cunda, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
translation_text.dn29:2.6: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and tell him about this.”
translation_text.dn29:3.1: Then Ānanda and Cunda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
translation_text.dn29:4.1: “That’s what happens, Cunda, when a teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:4.2: Take the case where a teacher is not awakened, and the teaching is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:4.3: A disciple in that teaching does not practice in line with the teaching, does not practice following that procedure, does not live in line with the teaching. They proceed having turned away from that teaching.
translation_text.dn29:4.4: You should say this to them,
translation_text.dn29:4.5: ‘You’re fortunate, reverend, you’re so very fortunate!
translation_text.dn29:4.6: For your teacher is not awakened, and their teaching is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:4.7: But you don’t practice in line with that teaching, you don’t practice following that procedure, you don’t live in line with the teaching. You proceed having turned away from that teaching.’
translation_text.dn29:4.8: In such a case the teacher and the teaching are to blame, but the disciple deserves praise.
translation_text.dn29:4.9: Suppose someone was to say to such a disciple,
translation_text.dn29:4.10: ‘Come on, venerable, practice as taught and pointed out by your teacher.’
translation_text.dn29:4.11: The one who encourages, the one who they encourage, and the one who practices accordingly all brim with much wickedness.
translation_text.dn29:4.13: It’s because that teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:5.1: Take the case where a teacher is not awakened, and the teaching is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:5.2: A disciple in that teaching practices in line with the teaching, practices following that procedure, lives in line with the teaching. They proceed having undertaken that teaching.
translation_text.dn29:5.3: You should say this to them,
translation_text.dn29:5.4: ‘It’s your loss, reverend, it’s your misfortune! For your teacher is not awakened, and their teaching is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:5.5: And you practice in line with that teaching, you practice following that procedure, you live in line with the teaching. You proceed having undertaken that teaching.’
translation_text.dn29:5.6: In such a case the teacher, the teaching, and the disciple are all to blame.
translation_text.dn29:5.7: Suppose someone was to say to such a disciple,
translation_text.dn29:5.8: ‘Clearly the venerable is practicing systematically and will succeed in that system.’
translation_text.dn29:5.9: The one who praises, the one who they praise, and the one who, being praised, rouses up even more energy all brim with much wickedness.
translation_text.dn29:5.11: It’s because that teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:6.1: Take the case where a teacher is awakened, and the teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.

translation_text.dn29:6.3: You should say this to them,
translation_text.dn29:6.4: ‘It’s your loss, reverend, it’s your misfortune! For your teacher is awakened, and their teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:6.5: But you don’t practice in line with that teaching, you don’t practice following that procedure, you don’t live in line with the teaching. You proceed having turned away from that teaching.’
translation_text.dn29:6.6: In such a case the teacher and the teaching deserve praise, but the disciple is to blame.
translation_text.dn29:6.7: Suppose someone was to say to such a disciple,
translation_text.dn29:6.8: ‘Come on, venerable, practice as taught and pointed out by your teacher.’
translation_text.dn29:6.9: The one who encourages, the one who they encourage, and the one who practices accordingly all brim with much merit.
translation_text.dn29:6.11: It’s because that teaching and training is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:7.1: Take the case where a teacher is awakened, and the teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:7.2: A disciple in that teaching practices in line with the teaching, practices following that procedure, lives in line with the teaching. They proceed having undertaken that teaching.
translation_text.dn29:7.3: You should say this to them,
translation_text.dn29:7.4: ‘You’re fortunate, reverend, you’re so very fortunate!
translation_text.dn29:7.5: For your teacher is awakened, and their teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:7.6: And you practice in line with that teaching, you practice following that procedure, you live in line with the teaching. You proceed having undertaken that teaching.’
translation_text.dn29:7.7: In such a case the teacher, the teaching, and the disciple all deserve praise.
translation_text.dn29:7.8: Suppose someone was to say to such a disciple,
translation_text.dn29:7.9: ‘Clearly the venerable is practicing systematically and will succeed in that system.’
translation_text.dn29:7.10: The one who praises, the one who they praise, and the one who, being praised, rouses up even more energy all brim with much merit.
translation_text.dn29:7.12: It’s because that teaching and training is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn29:8.1: Take the case where a teacher arises in the world who is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is fully awakened.
translation_text.dn29:8.2: But the disciples have not been educated in the meaning of that good teaching. And the spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure has not been disclosed and revealed to them; its sayings have not all been collected; and it has not been well proclaimed with its demonstrable basis wherever there are gods and humans.
translation_text.dn29:8.3: And then their teacher passes away.
translation_text.dn29:8.4: When such a teacher has passed away the disciples are tormented by regrets.
translation_text.dn29:8.6: They think: ‘Our teacher was perfected, a fully awakened Buddha. His teaching was well explained, but we were not educated in its meaning. And the spiritual practice was not fully disclosed and revealed to us; its sayings have not all been collected; and it has not been well proclaimed with its demonstrable basis wherever there are gods and humans.
translation_text.dn29:8.7: And then our teacher passed away.’
translation_text.dn29:8.8: When such a teacher has passed away the disciples are tormented by regrets.

translation_text.dn29:10.0: 5. On the Incomplete Spiritual Path, Etc.
translation_text.dn29:10.1: Now suppose, Cunda, that a spiritual path possesses those factors. But the teacher is not senior, long standing, long gone forth, advanced in years, and reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.dn29:10.2: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.
translation_text.dn29:10.3: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior,
translation_text.dn29:10.4: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.
translation_text.dn29:11.1: Now suppose that a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior. But there are no senior monk disciples who are competent, educated, assured, have attained sanctuary from the yoke,
translation_text.dn29:11.2: who can rightly explain the true teaching, and who can legitimately and completely refute the doctrines of others that come up, and teach with a demonstrable basis.
translation_text.dn29:11.3: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.
translation_text.dn29:12.1: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior and there are competent senior monks,
translation_text.dn29:12.3: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.
translation_text.dn29:12.4: Now suppose that a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior and there are competent senior monks.
translation_text.dn29:12.6: But there are no competent middle monks,
translation_text.dn29:12.15: There are white-clothed laywomen enjoying sensual pleasures, but the spiritual path is not successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans …
translation_text.dn29:12.16: the spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans, but it has not reached the peak of material things and fame.
translation_text.dn29:12.17: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.
translation_text.dn29:13.1: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior and there are competent senior monks,
translation_text.dn29:13.12: and the spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans, and it has reached the peak of material things and fame,
translation_text.dn29:13.13: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.
translation_text.dn29:14.1: I, Cunda, am a teacher who has arisen in the world today, perfected and fully awakened.
translation_text.dn29:14.2: The teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is fully awakened.
translation_text.dn29:14.3: My disciples have been educated in the meaning of that good teaching. And the spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure has been disclosed and revealed to them with all its collected sayings, with its demonstrable basis, well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.
translation_text.dn29:14.4: I am a teacher today who is senior, long standing, long gone forth, advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.dn29:15.1: I have today disciples who are competent senior monks,
translation_text.dn29:15.12: Today my spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.
translation_text.dn29:16.1: Of all the teachers in the world today, Cunda, I don’t see even a single one who has reached the peak of material things and fame like me.
translation_text.dn29:16.2: Of all the spiritual communities and groups in the world today, Cunda, I don’t see even a single one who has reached the pinnacle of material things and fame like the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn29:16.4: And if there’s any spiritual path of which it may be rightly said that
translation_text.dn29:16.5: it’s endowed with all good qualities, complete in all good qualities, neither too little nor too much, well explained, whole, full, and well propounded,
translation_text.dn29:16.6: it’s of this spiritual path that this should be said.
translation_text.dn29:16.8: Uddaka son of Rāma used to say:
translation_text.dn29:16.10: But seeing what does one not see?
translation_text.dn29:16.11: You can see the blade of a well-sharpened razor, but not the edge.
translation_text.dn29:16.14: But that saying of Uddaka’s is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless, as it’s only about a razor.
translation_text.dn29:16.15: If there’s anything of which it may be rightly said:
translation_text.dn29:16.16: ‘Seeing, one does not see,’ it’s of this that it should be said.
translation_text.dn29:16.18: Seeing what does one not see?
translation_text.dn29:16.19: One sees this: a spiritual path endowed with all good qualities, complete in all good qualities, neither too little nor too much, well explained, whole, full, and well propounded.
translation_text.dn29:16.20: One does not see this: anything that, were it to be removed, would make it purer.
translation_text.dn29:16.21: One does not see this: anything that, were it to be added, would make it more complete.
translation_text.dn29:17.0: 6. Teachings Should be Recited in Concert
translation_text.dn29:17.1: So, Cunda, you should all come together and recite in concert, without disputing, those things I have taught you from my direct knowledge, comparing meaning with meaning and phrasing with phrasing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
translation_text.dn29:17.2: And what are those things I have taught from my direct knowledge?
translation_text.dn29:17.3: They are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path.
translation_text.dn29:17.4: These are the things I have taught from my own direct knowledge.
translation_text.dn29:18.1: Suppose one of those spiritual companions who is training in harmony and mutual appreciation, without disputing, were to recite the teaching in the Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn29:18.3: ‘This venerable misconstrues the meaning and mistakes the phrasing.’

translation_text.dn29:18.7: ‘This phrasing fits the meaning better than that. And this meaning fits the phrasing better than that.’
translation_text.dn29:18.8: Without flattering or rebuking them, you should carefully persuade them by examining that meaning and that phrasing.

translation_text.dn29:22.1: Cunda, I do not teach you solely for restraining defilements that affect this life.
translation_text.dn29:22.2: Nor do I teach solely for protecting against defilements that affect lives to come.
translation_text.dn29:22.3: I teach both for restraining defilements that affect this life and
translation_text.dn29:22.4: protecting against defilements that affect lives to come.
translation_text.dn29:22.5: And that’s why I have allowed robes for you that suffice
translation_text.dn29:22.6: only for the sake of warding off cold and heat; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; and for covering up the private parts.
translation_text.dn29:22.7: I have allowed almsfood for you that suffices
translation_text.dn29:22.8: only to sustain this body, avoid harm, and support spiritual practice; so that you will put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and will keep on living blamelessly and at ease.
translation_text.dn29:22.9: I have allowed lodgings for you that suffice
translation_text.dn29:22.10: only for the sake of warding off cold and heat; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; to shelter from harsh weather and to enjoy retreat.
translation_text.dn29:22.11: I have allowed medicines and supplies for the sick for you that suffice
translation_text.dn29:22.12: only for the sake of warding off the pains of illness and to promote good health.
translation_text.dn29:23.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
translation_text.dn29:23.2: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan live indulging in pleasure.’
translation_text.dn29:23.5: For there are many different kinds of indulgence in pleasure.’
translation_text.dn29:23.6: These four kinds of indulgence in pleasure, Cunda, are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn29:23.8: It’s when some fool makes themselves happy and pleased by killing living creatures.
translation_text.dn29:23.9: This is the first kind of indulgence in pleasure.
translation_text.dn29:23.10: Furthermore, someone makes themselves happy and pleased by theft.
translation_text.dn29:23.11: This is the second kind of indulgence in pleasure.
translation_text.dn29:23.12: Furthermore, someone makes themselves happy and pleased by lying.
translation_text.dn29:23.13: This is the third kind of indulgence in pleasure.
translation_text.dn29:23.14: Furthermore, someone amuses themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.dn29:23.15: This is the fourth kind of indulgence in pleasure.
translation_text.dn29:23.16: These are the four kinds of indulgence in pleasure that are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn29:24.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
translation_text.dn29:24.2: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’
translation_text.dn29:24.4: It isn’t right to say that about you; it misrepresents you with an untruth.
translation_text.dn29:24.5: Cunda, these four kinds of indulgence in pleasure lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn29:24.7: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn29:24.8: This is the first kind of indulgence in pleasure.
translation_text.dn29:24.9: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption. It has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn29:24.10: This is the second kind of indulgence in pleasure.
translation_text.dn29:24.11: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.dn29:24.12: This is the third kind of indulgence in pleasure.
translation_text.dn29:24.13: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption. It is without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.dn29:24.14: This is the fourth kind of indulgence in pleasure.
translation_text.dn29:24.15: These are the four kinds of indulgence in pleasure which lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn29:24.16: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
translation_text.dn29:24.17: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’
translation_text.dn29:24.19: It’s right to say that about you; it doesn’t misrepresent you with an untruth.
translation_text.dn29:25.0: 10. The Benefits of Indulgence in Pleasure
translation_text.dn29:25.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
translation_text.dn29:25.2: ‘How many fruits and benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways?’
translation_text.dn29:25.4: ‘Four benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.
translation_text.dn29:25.6: Firstly, with the ending of three fetters a mendicant becomes a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.
translation_text.dn29:25.7: This is the first fruit and benefit.
translation_text.dn29:25.8: Furthermore, a mendicant—with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion—becomes a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.
translation_text.dn29:25.9: This is the second fruit and benefit.
translation_text.dn29:25.10: Furthermore, with the ending of the five lower fetters, a mendicant is reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.dn29:25.11: This is the third fruit and benefit.
translation_text.dn29:25.12: Furthermore, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn29:25.13: This is the fourth fruit and benefit.
translation_text.dn29:25.14: These four benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’
translation_text.dn29:26.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
translation_text.dn29:26.2: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan are fickle.’
translation_text.dn29:26.4: ‘Reverends, these things have been taught and pointed out for his disciples by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, not to be transgressed so long as life lasts.
translation_text.dn29:26.5: Suppose there was an Indra’s pillar or an iron pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable.
translation_text.dn29:26.6: In the same way, these things have been taught and pointed out for his disciples by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, not to be transgressed so long as life lasts.
translation_text.dn29:26.7: A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in nine respects.
translation_text.dn29:26.8: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they used to as a layperson. And they can’t make decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, or cowardice.
translation_text.dn29:26.9: A mendicant who is perfected can’t transgress in these nine respects.’
translation_text.dn29:27.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
translation_text.dn29:27.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama demonstrates boundless knowledge and vision of the past, but not of the future. What’s up with that?’
translation_text.dn29:27.3: Those wanderers, like incompetent fools, seem to imagine that one kind of knowledge and vision can be demonstrated by means of another kind of knowledge and vision.
translation_text.dn29:27.4: Regarding the past, the Realized One has knowledge stemming from memory.
translation_text.dn29:27.5: He recollects as far as he wants.
translation_text.dn29:27.6: Regarding the future, the Realized One has the knowledge born of awakening:
translation_text.dn29:27.7: ‘This is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’
translation_text.dn29:28.1: If a question about the past is untrue, false, and pointless, the Realized One does not reply.
translation_text.dn29:28.2: If a question about the past is true and correct, but pointless, he does not reply.
translation_text.dn29:28.3: If a question about the past is true, correct, and beneficial, he knows the right time to reply.
translation_text.dn29:28.4: And the Realized One replies to questions about the future or the present in the same way.
translation_text.dn29:28.8: And so the Realized One has speech that’s well-timed, true, meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
translation_text.dn29:29.1: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind, all that has been understood by the Realized One.
translation_text.dn29:29.2: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
translation_text.dn29:29.3: From the night when the Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—in the element of extinguishment with no residue—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.
translation_text.dn29:29.4: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
translation_text.dn29:29.5: The Realized One does as he says, and says as he does.
translation_text.dn29:29.6: Since this is so, that’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
translation_text.dn29:29.7: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—the Realized One is the vanquisher, the unvanquished, the universal seer, the wielder of power.
translation_text.dn29:30.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
translation_text.dn29:30.2: ‘Is this your view: “A Realized One exists after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile”?’
translation_text.dn29:30.4: ‘Reverend, this has not been declared by the Buddha.’
translation_text.dn29:30.7: ‘Then is this your view: “A Realized One doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile”?’
translation_text.dn29:30.9: ‘This too has not been declared by the Buddha.’
translation_text.dn29:30.12: ‘Then is this your view: “A Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile”?’
translation_text.dn29:30.14: ‘This too has not been declared by the Buddha.’
translation_text.dn29:30.17: ‘Then is this your view: “A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile”?’
translation_text.dn29:30.19: ‘This too has not been declared by the Buddha.’
translation_text.dn29:31.2: ‘But why has this not been declared by the ascetic Gotama?’
translation_text.dn29:31.4: ‘Because it’s not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That’s why it hasn’t been declared by the Buddha.’
translation_text.dn29:32.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
translation_text.dn29:32.2: ‘But what has been declared by the ascetic Gotama?’
translation_text.dn29:32.4: ‘What has been declared by the Buddha is this: “This is suffering”—“This is the origin of suffering”—“This is the cessation of suffering”—“This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.”’
translation_text.dn29:33.2: ‘But why has this been declared by the ascetic Gotama?’
translation_text.dn29:33.4: ‘Because it’s beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That’s why it has been declared by the Buddha.’
translation_text.dn29:34.1: Cunda, I have explained to you as they should be explained the views that some rely on regarding the first beginning.
translation_text.dn29:34.2: Shall I explain them to you in the wrong way?
translation_text.dn29:34.3: I have explained to you as they should be explained the views that some rely on regarding the final end.
translation_text.dn29:34.4: Shall I explain them to you in the wrong way?
translation_text.dn29:34.5: What are the views that some rely on regarding the first beginning?
translation_text.dn29:34.7: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.dn29:34.8: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.dn29:34.9: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.dn29:34.10: ‘The self and the cosmos are not eternal,
translation_text.dn29:34.11: or both eternal and not eternal,
translation_text.dn29:34.12: or neither eternal nor not eternal.
translation_text.dn29:34.13: The self and the cosmos are made by oneself,
translation_text.dn29:34.15: or made by both oneself and another,
translation_text.dn29:34.16: or they have arisen anomalously, not made by oneself or another.
translation_text.dn29:34.19: or both eternal and not eternal,
translation_text.dn29:34.20: or neither eternal nor not eternal.
translation_text.dn29:34.21: Pleasure and pain are made by oneself,
translation_text.dn29:34.23: or made by both oneself and another,
translation_text.dn29:34.24: or they have arisen anomalously, not made by oneself or another. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

translation_text.dn29:35.5: “The self and the cosmos are eternal”?’
translation_text.dn29:35.7: This is the only truth, anything else is futile,’

translation_text.dn29:35.12: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher exposition.

translation_text.dn29:36.22: And in each case, I don’t grant that.
translation_text.dn29:36.24: Because there are beings who have different opinions on this topic.
translation_text.dn29:36.25: I don’t see any such expositions that are equal to my own, still less superior.
translation_text.dn29:36.26: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher exposition.
translation_text.dn29:36.27: These are the views that some rely on regarding the first beginning.
translation_text.dn29:37.1: What are the views that some rely on regarding the final end?
translation_text.dn29:37.3: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.dn29:37.4: ‘The self is healthy after death, and formed …
translation_text.dn29:37.12: or the self is annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.dn29:38.1: Regarding this, I go up to the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that,
translation_text.dn29:38.2: ‘The self is formed and healthy after death,’
translation_text.dn29:38.5: “The self is formed and healthy after death”?’
translation_text.dn29:38.7: This is the only truth, anything else is futile,’
translation_text.dn29:38.10: Because there are beings who have different opinions on this topic.
translation_text.dn29:38.11: I don’t see any such expositions that are equal to my own, still less superior.
translation_text.dn29:38.12: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher exposition.
translation_text.dn29:39.1: Regarding this, I go up to the ascetics and brahmins who assert all the other views as described above.
translation_text.dn29:39.14: And in each case, I don’t grant that.
translation_text.dn29:39.16: Because there are beings who have different opinions on this topic.
translation_text.dn29:39.17: I don’t see any such expositions that are equal to my own, still less superior.
translation_text.dn29:39.18: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher exposition.
translation_text.dn29:39.19: These are the views that some rely on regarding the final end, which I have explained to you as they should be explained.
translation_text.dn29:39.20: Shall I explain them to you in the wrong way?
translation_text.dn29:40.1: I have taught and pointed out the four kinds of mindfulness meditation for giving up and going beyond all these views of the first beginning and the final end.
translation_text.dn29:40.3: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn29:40.4: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
translation_text.dn29:40.6: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn29:40.7: These are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I have taught for giving up and going beyond all these views of the first beginning and the final end.”
translation_text.dn29:41.1: Now at that time Venerable Upavāṇa was standing behind the Buddha fanning him.
translation_text.dn29:41.4: This exposition of the teaching is impressive, sir,
translation_text.dn29:41.5: it is very impressive. Sir, what is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”
translation_text.dn29:41.6: “Well then, Upavāṇa, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Impressive Discourse’.”
translation_text.dn29:41.7: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn29:41.8: Satisfied, Venerable Upavāṇa approved what the Buddha said.
